It strengthens my resolve to continue working — through education — to build the kind of strong, knowledge-driven health system our nation deserves.

The KAARC seamlessly aligns with Mr. President’s Renewed Hope Agenda for Education, where we are committed to building world-class learning and research environments for our students, teachers, and institutions.

I extend my profound gratitude to Sir (Dr.) Kensington Adebukola Adebutu, OON, CON, CFR, KJW, FISM, FNIJ, FAMedS, a distinguished Nigerian philanthropist and visionary for gifting MEDILAG with this remarkable facility — one that will advance research, push boundaries, and heal lives.

It gives me great pleasure to officially launch a landmark initiative that speaks directly to the heart of our commitment to the welfare and professional growth of our nation’s tertiary institution workforce — the Tertiary Institutions Staff Support Fund (TISSF).

TISSF is not just a welfare package; it is a strategic empowerment platform designed to give our academic and non-academic staff the financial stability they need to serve our students with renewed dedication, and to live with dignity and pride.

It is an integral part of President @officialABAT, GCFR’s Renewed Hope Reform Agenda for Education, which places our people — our greatest asset — at the centre of transforming our education sector and growing our economy.

TISSF is a joint initiative of the Federal Ministry of Education and the Tertiary Education Trust Fund (TETFund), implemented in partnership with the @BOINigeria. It is a free, 0% interest loan scheme aimed at enhancing welfare, supporting career development, and promoting financial independence for staff in Nigerian tertiary institutions.

What do staff get?
•Up to ₦10 million (capped at 33.3% of gross annual salary) — repayable after 5 years, with a 12-month moratorium before repayment begins.

What does TISSF cover?
I. Medical Support: Surgeries, emergency care, medication.
II. Family & Accommodation Support: Rent, home ownership, renovation.
III. Transportation: Vehicle purchase (including EVs), bikes, tricycles, CNG conversions.
IV. Small-Scale Enterprise & Agriculture: Poultry, fishing, crop farming, agro-processing.
V. Academic Advancement: Professional certifications, degrees, capacity-building programmes.

Who’s eligible?
• Confirmed full-time academic and non-academic staff of any federal university, polytechnic, or college of education.
• One state university, polytechnic, and college of education in each state.
• Applicants with at least five (5) years remaining until retirement.
• Membership of relevant staff associations such as ASUU, SSANU, NASU, etc.

To all eligible staff across our universities, polytechnics, and colleges of education: begin your application today. It’s time to seize the moment!

On Monday, we held the inaugural meeting of the National Steering Committee for the Human Capital Opportunities for Prosperity and Equity (#HOPE) project, which includes HOPE-Education, HOPE-Health, and HOPE-Gov.

The Steering Committee comprises the Minister of Budget, Senator @atikuabagudu; the Minister of Finance and Coordinating Minister of the Economy, Mr. Wale Edun, @FinMinNigeria; the Coordinating Minister of Health and Social Welfare (CMHSW), Prof. @muhammadpate; myself @NigEducation; and the three National Programme Coordinators. In this regard, the Honourable Minister of Women Affairs, Hajiya Imaan Sulaiman-Ibrahim, @hm_womenaffairs, was also in attendance to ensure inclusive participation and synergy from the outset.

This HOPE initiative further exemplifies President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, GCFR’s, unwavering belief in human capital development—particularly in education, health, and social protection. The President remains deeply committed to advancing these investments to unlock significant demographic dividends for the Nigerian people.

We are building a nation where young Nigerians are well-educated, have access to quality healthcare, and are empowered to become a strong and productive workforce.

HOPE-Education is a $552 million programme co-financed by the World Bank and the Global Partnership for Education (GPE). It focuses on three key pillars:
1. Improving the quality of education,

2. Expanding access to quality education, and

3. Strengthening education systems across all states.

The programme places special emphasis on foundational learning, teacher professional development, data and digitalization, and reducing the number of out-of-school children.
By the end of the project, we aim to reach:
• 29 million children,
• 500,000 public school teachers,
• 65,000 public schools, and
• 10,000 non-formal learning centres.

BRIDGE—Diaspora Bridging Research, Innovation, Development, and Global Engagement—is the Federal Ministry of Education’s (FME) initiative designed to ensure Nigerian academia and medical institutions benefit from global expertise, funding opportunities, industry linkages, and knowledge transfer.

The portal, set to launch in May 2025, creates structured pathways for Nigerian scholars and professionals abroad to engage meaningfully with institutions back home—bridging gaps in teaching, medical service provision, research capacity, teaching methodologies, and industry relevance.

As a fellow returnee, once eager to contribute to the transformation of our great nation, I felt it was only fitting—now as Minister of Education—to simplify the process through which Nigerians in the diaspora can give back and support national development.

#BRIDGE is a game-changer in how the country engages with diaspora Nigerian professionals in academia, medical sciences, the arts, industry, and other sectors. Such engagement is essential for unlocking Nigeria’s untapped potential and driving transformative change across our society.

As part of BRIDGE’s rollout, today we are demonstrating the platform’s capabilities at ANPA Lagos. Next week, we will engage Vice-Chancellors, Rectors, and Provosts of our tertiary institutions on onboarding their institutions onto the platform and connecting with the diaspora community.

PRESS RELEASE

ENSURING STUDENT WELFARE: FEDERAL MINISTRY OF EDUCATION INVESTIGATES FOOD QUALITY IN FEDERAL UNITY COLLEGES 

The Federal Ministry of Education has reaffirmed its commitment to the well-being of students in Federal Unity Colleges following a recent inspection of some the Colleges.

During the visit by Ministry officials, it was discovered that two Colleges provided meals that did not meet the required standards for students. In response, the Principals of the affected schools have been recalled to the Ministry’s headquarters to allow for investigation.

To ensure strict compliance with standard feeding and students welfare, the Ministry has deployed senior officers to monitor the operations of the affected Colleges while the investigation is going on. Additionally, the Ministry has initiated a nationwide assessment of all Federal Unity Colleges to evaluate the quality of food and pastoral care provided to students.

The Federal Ministry of Education remains steadfast in its duty to uphold high standards in its Colleges , ensuring that students receive the proper nourishment and care necessary for their academic and personal development.

Boriowo Folasade
Director, Press & Public Relations
Federal Ministry of Education

As I wrap up my duties as Minister of State for Health & Social Welfare, @Fmohnigeria, I was pleased to attend the 27th Annual Scientific Conference and Annual General Meeting of the Medical Association of Nigerians Across Great Britain (MANSAG) @MANSAG_uk. 

The theme of this year’s conference, “The Future of Healthcare – A Global Perspective,” could not be more timely. To navigate the complex systemic challenges we currently face and those that lie ahead, international cooperation is critical.

I believe that one of the most immediate and impactful areas for engagement is between our government and our partners in the United Kingdom, such as MANSAG. As a leading Nigerian medical organization in the diaspora, with over 15,000 medical professionals, MANSAG plays a crucial role in shaping the future of healthcare in the British Isles, Nigeria, and beyond.

We, as a government, are extremely proud of our diaspora community and are committed to building on their skills to strengthen Nigeria’s healthcare system.

However, we know that leveraging the full potential of diaspora engagement is not without its challenges. That is why we are proactively addressing these issues and have set up the Nigerian Health Professionals in Diaspora Engagement Programme to harness the expertise of diaspora healthcare professionals.

Through this programme, we aim to establish a two-way knowledge exchange between our healthcare professionals abroad and those working in Nigeria, via Specialized Medical Missions, Training and Capacity Building, Public-Private Partnerships, and Research and Innovation.

The challenges we face are immense, but with stronger partnerships with local and international organisations, institutions and partners, we can build a future where every Nigerian has access to quality healthcare.

I extend my thanks to the President of MANSAG for his willingness to support our initiatives and plans.

PRESS STATEMENT 

FINALIZATION OF EXECUTIVE ORDER ON ZERO VAT FOR PHARMACEUTICAL MANUFACTURERS

The Ministry of Health and Social Welfare @Fmohnigeria,  is pleased to announce the finalization of the Executive Order Harmonized Implementation Framework, which has now been cleared for gazetting. This critical step ensures that the Federal Inland Revenue Service (FIRS) and the Nigeria Customs Service can proceed with the implementation of zero VAT and excise duties on pharmaceutical products and medical devices. This is a significant milestone, as it opens the door for our local pharmaceutical and medical device manufacturers to begin fully benefiting from the relief measures outlined by His Excellency, President Bola Ahmed Tinubu @officialABAT, in the Executive Order.

With the implementation of this Executive Order, we anticipate a notable reduction in the prices of essential pharmaceutical products and medical consumables. This development aligns with the Ministry’s unwavering commitment to reducing both the physical and financial pain faced by millions of Nigerians who depend on these critical health supplies.

Furthermore, the gazetting of the Harmonized Implementation Framework represents the realization of the third pillar of the Ministry’s 4-point agenda, which focuses on unlocking the healthcare value chain. By creating an environment that supports local manufacturers, we are fostering a healthier, more self-reliant nation, and ensuring that quality healthcare becomes more accessible and affordable for all.

The gazetted copies of the Harmonized Implementation Framework will be distributed to the relevant government agencies, including @FIRSNigeria and @CustomsNG for immediate action.

Undoubtedly, today is another great day for our country and a huge win for the health sector. We are grateful to President BAT, for his continued commitment to improving the healthcare sector and supporting our local industries.

1. Strengthening Bilateral Relationships: We explored ways to further enhance the collaboration between the Federal Government of Nigeria and international atomic energy agency. Specifically, we focused on expanding cancer care and treatment in Nigeria. This includes a partnership with the IAEA’s ‘Rays of Hope’ Fund  with our own @NicratGov to conduct  needs assessment for comprehensive cancer care across all 36 states and 774 local government areas in Nigeria. 

2. Building Partnerships for Funding: We also discussed the importance of forging additional partnerships with funding organizations such as the OPEC Fund and the Islamic Development Bank to support our ambitious goal of expanding cancer care that will enable our Country to have enough penetration  for advanced Cancer Care technologies that will include LINACs, PET scans and cyclotrons,

3. IAEA’s Support for Gamma Cameras: Mr. Grossi agreed to help support  Nigeria with Gamma cameras for the National Hospital Abuja. Additionally, the IAEA will assist in removing the decayed isotopes from our six cancer centers equipped with brachytherapy machines and providing replacements. 
Also IAEA will support provision of dosimetry and transluminescent sensors.

4. Nuclear Medicine Program: We updated Mr. Grossi on the Federal Ministry of Health and Social Welfare @Fmohnigeria’s commitment to launching a Nuclear Medicine residency program. Following significant collaboration with the National Postgraduate Medical College and the West African College of Surgeons, the Nuclear Medicine residency program will commence this September 2024 at both the National Hospital Abuja @NatHospital_ABJ and the University College Hospital Ibadan @uchibadan_ .

Mr. Grossi expressed his admiration for Nigeria’s progress since his initial visit in May. In line with our commitment to strengthening our relationship with the IAEA, the federal government has paid Nigeria’s outstanding dues to the IAEA, including contributions to the National Obligation Fund, Technical Cooperation Fund, National Participation Fund, and the African Regional Agreement Fund.

text:
I was immensely pleased and proud to inaugurate the National Taskforce on Antimicrobial Stewardship (AMS) today in Abuja, in alignment with our 4-point agenda, specifically Pillar 2 (Improving Health Outcomes) and Pillar 4 (Health Security).

Antimicrobial resistance (#AMR) is a silent but deadly threat that has taken root globally, including in Nigeria. #Nigeria ranks 18th worldwide in AMR-related deaths. In 2019, there were 64,500 deaths directly attributable to AMR and 263,400 deaths associated with AMR, surpassing fatalities from enteric infections, respiratory infections, tuberculosis, maternal and neonatal disorders, neglected tropical diseases, malaria, and cardiovascular diseases.

Currently, Nigeria lacks an AMS program to monitor antimicrobial use and sensitivity patterns across its regions. This poses a serious risk of escalating antimicrobial resistance, leading to increased morbidity and mortality.

Today's inauguration marks a crucial step in our nation’s healthcare journey and underscores our government’s commitment to tackling one of the most pressing public health challenges of our time.

The taskforce is composed of distinguished experts in infectious diseases, public health practitioners, academics, representatives from multilateral groups focused on AMR, and officials from the Federal Ministry of Health and Social Welfare (FMOH&SW).

To address AMR effectively, the taskforce will:
1. Coordinate AMR surveillance and research activities in Nigeria.
2. Develop an AMR data platform.
3. Promote education and awareness about AMR.

Routine education and widespread awareness are essential for reducing AMR-related deaths. 

On behalf of the @Fmohnigeria, I extend my sincere gratitude to Prof Stephen Obaro, world renowned Paediatric Infectious Disease expert, the Taskforce’s National Coordinator, Dr. Omobosola Akinsete and all committee members for their dedication to this critical cause.

I would also like to thank all our development partners their unwavering support.

The task before us is urgent and requires unwavering commitment. Together, we can combat antimicrobial resistance and safeguard the health of our people, fulfilling the mandate set by our President, @officialABAT, GCFR.

The theme of the day was #malaria.

Yesterday, we also held the inaugural meeting of the National Intermittent Preventive Treatment in School Children (IPTsc) Research and Policy Uptake Task Team (NISPRPUT).

Studies indicate that school-age #children (SAC) between the ages of 5-15 years bear a high burden of malaria. It is disheartening that this demographic has been overlooked in many malaria control interventions, despite comprising 26 percent of the African population.

The Federal Ministry of Health & Social Welfare's National Malaria Elimination Programme is planning a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) on IPTsc to assess the protective effects of Sulphadoxine-Pyrimethamine plus Amodiaquine (SPAQ) and Dihydroartemisinin-Piperaquine (DHP) in SAC in Sokoto and Cross River States from September 2024 to December 2025. It is important to note that resistance to these drugs has not been recorded in the country, and continuous monitoring is in place to ensure this remains the case.

The NISPRPUT task team consists of experts from various ministries, departments, agencies, programs, academia, and professional organizations, carefully chosen to facilitate decision-making for the adoption of IPTsc policies based on data generated from the RCT study.

Given that malaria is a major contributor to absenteeism in schools and workplaces, our hope is that focusing on SAC will further reduce malaria prevalence in Nigeria.

Additionally, the study will complement existing malaria prevention strategies, i.e. insecticide-treated nets, seasonal malaria chemoprevention, and intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy, as well as improve malaria surveillance and treatment outcomes.

I am confident that the collective wisdom, expertise, and dedication of the task team will guide the assessment of the intervention and provide the data needed to make informed decisions for the wellbeing and betterment of Nigerians.

On behalf of the @Fmohnigeria, I commend our partners, the Ministries of Education and World Bank, for their efforts and look forward to the results of the study.

On Thursday, June 27th, I had the pleasure of dining with the Federation of Nigerian Pharmaceutical Associations (FeNPIA).

The dinner provided an opportunity to hear about FeNPIA’s challenges, current bottlenecks, their goals, and to discuss how the Federal Ministry of Health & Social Welfare @Fmohnigeria (FMOH&SW) can offer support.

Ensuring Nigeria’s pharmaceutical industry thrives through local medical industrialization is an integral part of the President’s Renewed Hope Agenda and Pillar 3, "Unlocking the Value Chain," of the Federal Ministry of Health & Social Welfare’s 4-point agenda.

To foster national growth, it is crucial that we increase our manufacturing capacity, production, sales, and exportation of health products. This is why we have diligently worked on an Executive Order aimed at boosting local production of pharmaceuticals, diagnostics, devices (such as needles and syringes), biologicals, etc. This order was signed by the President on Friday, June 28th.

The Order introduces zero tariffs, excise taxes, and VAT on specified machinery, equipment, and raw materials, such as Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (#APIs), excipients, solvents, disintegrants, etc., necessary for producing essential health medicines and products. This means existing and new manufacturers can now engage in end-to-end pharmaceutical production processes.

Our hope is that the Executive Order will incentivize and support Nigerian #manufacturers, reduce production costs associated with imports, enhance the competitiveness of local manufacturers, create more jobs, and boost our economic value.

I extend heartfelt thanks to President Bola Ahmed Tinubu @officialABAT for listening to the concerns of the people and for his commitment to reaffirming Nigeria’s position as a leading nation.

I would also like to thank the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of the Federation, Prince Lateef @LOFagbemi , for initiating the codification process of the order, as well as all ministries and stakeholders who provided guidance and support in bringing this Executive Order to fruition. The Order is a collaborative effort across ministries, necessitating cross-sector cooperation for its swift implementation.

In our rapidly evolving world, digital transformation is no longer a luxury but a necessity. The COVID-19 pandemic has starkly highlighted gaps and challenges in global health systems, emphasizing the urgent need for innovative solutions to ensure resilient and responsive healthcare delivery.

Digital health solutions have the potential to significantly improve patient care and safety, streamline processes, reduce errors, and facilitate more accurate diagnoses and treatments. They also enable us to reach underserved populations and enhance the efficiency of healthcare systems by reducing costs and optimizing resource allocation.

Under the visionary leadership of our President, @officialABAT , GCFR, Prof. @muhammadpate and I have been tasked with ensuring the full digitization of our health system, recognizing it as a key enabler to achieving quality healthcare and Universal Health Coverage (UHC) for all Nigerians.

Aligned with the President's Renewed Hope Agenda and the FMOH&SW’s 4-pillar agenda, we have established the Nigeria Digital in Health Initiative (NDHI), governed by a 20-member committee, to transform the country’s healthcare delivery system using a unified and interoperable digital health architecture.

Since the inauguration of the NDHI’s Implementation Committee, we have reviewed existing national and international standards, frameworks, and policies, and engaged with various stakeholders including digital health solutions providers.

As the next step, we are proud to launch the NDHI website, https://t.co/0VnOG9FGSN. This website serves as a one-stop shop for information about the NDHI, our progress, and communication activities. I urge all stakeholders and digital health solution providers to join our community. This is an opportunity for all of us to work together towards our collective goal of creating the healthcare system we deserve.

Today, we marked the public presentation of the National Cancer Registry Regulations for Nigeria.

The National Cancer Registry Regulations offer a platform for continuous professional development and collaboration. They will improve access to real-time data, promote early detection through timely diagnosis and intervention, and help mitigate the impact of #cancer on individuals and communities, thereby significantly improving the quality of healthcare delivery in Nigeria.

By mandating healthcare providers to report cancer cases to centralized registries, @Fmohnigeria aims to create a comprehensive database that accurately reflects the burden of cancer within the country. This data-driven approach is essential for formulating evidence-based policies, allocating resources effectively, and monitoring the effectiveness of interventions over time.

Cancer is a global health crisis, and Nigeria is no exception. It is estimated that over 124,000 new cases of cancer were recorded in Nigeria in 2020, resulting in 78,899 deaths. The prevalence of cancer is rising at an alarming rate, posing a significant threat to the health and well-being of our people.

On behalf of the @Fmohnigeria, I extend my sincere appreciation to the Nigeria Institute of Cancer Research and Treatment (@NicratGov) and their partners: the African Cancer Registry Network, International Agency for Research on Cancer, and St Jude’s Children’s Research Hospital USA, for developing this important document. This collaborative effort is essential for building a resilient healthcare system capable of addressing the growing burden of cancer in Nigeria.

It is our hope that this will translate into concrete actions that advance our collective fight against cancer.

On Tuesday, June 25th, 2024, the Federal Executive Council (FEC) convened to address several urgent issues. The agenda encompassed key sectors of the economy, including health, minimum wage, and environmental concerns. Regarding health, the council focused on four main areas: infrastructure, public health issues such as the current #cholera outbreak, and child and maternal malnutrition.

In terms of organizational structure for healthcare regulatory agencies, tertiary hospitals, Federal Medical Centres (FMCs), and Federal Specialist Hospitals (FSHs), the council approved guidelines specifying that regulatory agencies will have 13 board members and 5 statutory members, while teaching hospitals, FMCs, and FSHs will each have 7 board members and 3 statutory members.

The council and the President authorized the Attorney General to amend the acts governing regulatory agencies, tertiary hospitals, Federal Medical Centres, and specialist hospitals to align with the newly approved regulations and board compositions.

Due to the increasing incidence of maternal and child malnutrition, the council approved a plan to distribute 'ready-to-eat' nutritional food within the coming weeks. Approval was granted for the Coordinating Minister of the Economy to mobilize funds for purchasing locally manufactured 'ready-to-eat' food, which will be distributed to states identified with high rates of malnutrition. This initiative aims to support local manufacturing capacity and promote industrialization.

Precision community health will also ensure that these advancements equitably reach our populations, bridging gaps in care and fostering healthier communities.

text:
Biotechnology holds immense promise for the advancement of healthcare, agriculture, environmental sustainability, and various other sectors. It has the potential to revolutionize our method of approach to challenges and provide effective solutions if harnessed in a responsible and safe manner.

I was pleased to attend the Biotechnology and Biosafety Stakeholders forum today, aiming to discuss the influence and benefits of Genetically Modified crops and animals on farming, crop production and food scarcity.

In adherence with the Federal Ministry of Health and Social Welfare 4-point agenda, we are going to collaborate synergistically with the Federal Ministry of Environment, Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security (FMAFS), National Biotechnology Development Agency (NABDA) and National Biosafety Management Agency (NBMA) to push forward the “One Health” Approach, which favours an integrated, unifying approach to sustainably balance and optmise the health of people, animals and ecosystem, as they are closely linked and interdependent.

Nigeria can only become a food secure nation and by implication, Africa’s ‘Blue Zone’, if we adopt modern technologies to enhance the way we produce our food – which is at the core of the Renewed Hope Agenda of HE President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, GCFR @officialABAT 

In order to become Africa’s Blue Zone, it is important that we change the narrative of GMO crops. Since its introduction over 30 years ago, over 2,000 studies have been conducted to evaluate the health and related aspects of genetically engineered products. These studies have found nothing to indicate that GM foods possess a health threat and predispose humans to higher health risk than conventional foods. 

Biotechnology presents the healthcare sector with boundless opportunities for the development of novel therapies, diagnostics, and preventive measures. By embracing biotechnological advancements, we can work towards addressing pressing public health challenges and improving the well-being of our citizens.

The @Fmohnigeria is committed to supporting and advancing the safe and responsible application of biotechnology in our healthcare system and eager to collaborate with all stakeholders to develop policies and regulations that promote innovation while safeguarding public health and environmental integrity.

It’s time we work together to pave the way for a future where biotechnology and biosafety work hand in hand to create a healthier, more sustainable, and prosperous society for all Nigerians.

text:
In honour of  #WorldMalariaDay, I’d like to call all everyone to join me in taking a stance against malaria.  

Malaria is still a major public health challenge for our country, with rising morbidity rates each day, but under the leadership of HE President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, we are determined to reduce the burden to an insignificant level and finally eliminate it from our shores.

Our resolve is evident in @FMoHsW’sin our 4-point agenda, particularly pillar 3 of unlocking the value chain to increase local industrialisation and the ongoing implementation of the National Malaria Strategic Plan 2021-2025 via the National Malaria Elimination Program which aims to:

1. Improve access and utilization of vector control interventions to at least 80% of targeted population by 2025.
2. Ensure provision of chemoprevention, diagnosis and appropriate treatment for 80% of the target populations at risk by 2025.
3. Improve generation of evidence for decision making and impact through reporting of quality malaria data and information from at least 80% of health facilities (public and private) and other data sources including surveillance, surveys and operations research by 2025.
4. Strengthen coordination, collaboration, and strategic partnership to promote efficiency and effectiveness of malaria control activities towards achieving at least 75% improvement from baseline using a standardized OCA tool.
5. Improve funding for malaria control by at least 25% annually through predictable and innovative sources to ensure sustainability at federal and sub-national levels.

Our overall goal is to reduce parasite prevalence of less than 10% and reduce malaria mortality to less than 50 deaths per 1,000 livebirths by 2025. 

We are still on the path to meet the Global technical strategy for Malaria 2030 (GTS) and achieve Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 3.3, calling to end epidemics of malaria and other communicable diseases by 2030.

As previously mentioned, following my trip to Cameroon earlier this year, the FMOH will be  hosting a Rethinking Malaria Elimination Event next week to conclude on our strategies to implement Malaria in our SWAP programme, unlock the treatment value chain and further discuss how to fast track the elimination of Malaria. 

Eradicating Malaria in all 36 states will take time but if we all start taking the necessary steps to prevent it and protect ourselves, we are one step closer to eradication. 

#ZeroMalariaStartsWithMe and it can start with you too.

Research serves as the cornerstone of society and is essential for scientific progress. To revitalize our healthcare sector, it’s crucial to prioritize the creation of a conducive environment for medical and clinical research.

I was pleased to meet a group of experts from the University or Chicago, Professor Alex Pearson and  Professor Birali Runesa, working with Nigerian doctors to train Nigerians on Data Science and Medical Image Analysis (DATICAN). 

DATICAN is a NIH funded project led by Professor Aribisala, Lagos State University, aimed at training 72 graduates and postgraduates. The programme is currently being implemented in University of Chicago, Lagos State University, University of Ibadan and Redeemer’s University. At the end of the course, enrolled participants will get MSc or PhD degree and a certificate of participation.

To expand their impact, DATICAN is collaborating with the Growing Data Science Research in Africa to stimulate Progress (GRASP) to train a further 1000 graduate students and postdocs in data-intensive health research, over a 5 year period. Initiated by Professor Olopade, NHRC Chair, the GRASP & DATICAN program will last for 10 months and be implemented at 6 institutions across the country (2x east, 2x north, 2x south). 

In line with Mr President’s mandate to make Nigeria a hub for medical and health research, I have recommended other institutions in the country i.e, University of Maiduguri, FMC Nguru, Birin Kebbi , Abu Zaria, UNTH , Uyo Teaching Hospital , FMC Jabi and National Hospital Abuja, to host the data science training program in addition to UCH and LASUTH. 

Under my leadership with support from Prof Pate, the FMOHSW will support the GRASP & DATICAN project to train the 1000 students by providing High Processing Computers (HPC) for the students which will be housed at NICRAT for continuity and to support the cancer registry being established at NICRAT. 

Unlocking the research value chain and promoting clinical research and development is a pivotal pillar in our 4 point agenda that’s vital to the success of the health system rejuvenation. The ministry is aware of the many issues affecting research undertaking in the country. That’s why we are implementing short to longterm solutions to help address the energy crisis in hospitals by providing infrastructure for solar power and challenges with Visa applications. Regarding grants and funding, Prof Pate and I with full support from Mr President are working on a Health Research Fund that will be dedicated to meeting our health research needs. 

I extend thanks to Prof Aribisala, Prof Olapade, Professor Alex Pearson, Professor Mayowa Owolabi and Professor Birali Runesa. I look forward to working with you to support healthcare and medical professionals.

Commencing the event in Lagos State today, we distributed 72 Hilux Project vehicles and medical equipment procured by The Global Fund to enhance efforts against HIV/AIDS, TB, and Malaria.

The event followed a strategic meeting led by Mark Eddington, Head of Grant Management at The Global Fund’s Country Coordinating Mechanism (CCM), with @ProfAkinAbayomi , Special Advisor to Gov. @jidesanwoolu , Dr (Mrs) Kemi Ogunyemi, Perm Sec of Lagos State MOH Dr Segun Ogboye. 

Last year, Nigeria diagnosed over 300,000 tuberculosis (TB) cases. This was the first time in our history of ever recoding such a high number of TB diagnoses, meaning our TB case finding has risen from 24% to 68%.

The equitable distribution of the equipment and vehicles across the 36 states and FCT will support our National response to HIV/AIDS and Tuberculosis, and state governments' oversight of integrated HIV and TB programs statewide — a critical component of the response strategy.

In alignment with the National Alignment 2.0 agreement, the Federal Government is aiming to decentralise responsibilities and shift ownership, coordination and management of the national response from us to the states and local government. As it will help to build a more resilient and sustainable system for health in Nigeria. 

Lagos state has made commendable efforts to reduce HIV/AIDS, TB and Malaria prevalence, but it is time for the other states to follow suit and invest in building capacity to achieve similar success. 

Instead of following old patterns, I’m urging State and Local governments to become more flexible and adaptable with their approaches to address emerging challenges. We need better resource allocation, coordination and more effective strategies to eliminate these diseases and achieve our long-term health goals like Universal Health coverage. 

The Global Fund has been and remains a strategic partner to The Federal Republic of Nigeria for over 2 decades. In the past three years, The Global fund had donated 333 units of Quatro TrueNat Machine, 100 units of TB-Lamp machines, 350 units of mobile digital X-Ray machines, 45 units of the Class II Biological Safety Cabinet (BSC) and 2 units of Mobile Chest X- Ray. 

It is imperative that we build sustainable capacity within the country to ensure progress continues even without external support.  In line with our 4 point agenda we are committed to providing the necessary support and complementary funding to ensure availability of HIV tests, including HIV self- testing kits.

Today marked a pivotal moment in Nigeria’s healthcare landscape. 

We inaugurated the Implementation Committee for Nigeria’s Digital in Health Initiative. A 20-person multi-sectoral committee, comprising of a diverse group of individuals with extensive experience and pertinent skills in digital health, technology, healthcare administration. 

Digitalising the healthcare system is one of the key elements to achieving President Bola Ahmed Tinubu GCFR’s vision for the health sector. Having quality data available for use, is a key enabler that also underpins the entire health delivery system’s framework and is vital to the FMOHSW’s 4-point agenda.

The Implementation Committee will midwife data policy, regulation, repository management and serve as an ombudsman to establish and scale-up of our digital health interventions i.e, a national unified Electronic Medical Record (EMR) platform. 

A national EMR system would enable primary, secondary, and tertiary healthcare personnel to manage clinical and administrative data seamlessly across centres and achieve improved quality of care, reduce expenditure and increase staff capacity and productivity.

Utilising existing national digital health policies and frameworks, the committee will be responsible for managing the deployment, architectural design and pilot of the EMR platform, as well as other overarching activities to drive our health digitalisation agenda.

The EMR platform pilot will initially begin at the federal tertiary hospitals and be implemented in one state per geo-political zone, to gauge its efficiency and accuracy.

The inauguration of this committee symbolises the strides we are taking towards establishing a national digital healthcare architecture and our steadfast dedication to fulfilling the President’s mandate to deliver Universal Health Coverage (UHC) for all Nigerians and regain our status as a leading nation in health productivity and care delivery. 

I extend gratitude to our development partners for their support and collaboration, and my deepest appreciation to the members of the Implementation Committee for Nigeria’s Digital in Health Initiative for accepting this responsibility. Together, I am confident in our ability to create the digital ecosystem we desire.

This week I had the pleasure of attending @WHO’s Malaria Ministerial Conference in Yaoundé, Cameroon, themed “Tackling Malaria in countries hit by the disease”.

In the past couple of years, we have made moderate progress to reduce malaria parasite prevalence (from 27% — 22%), and #malaria deaths (from 92 to 87 per 100,000 population) with the help of our development partners. However, we are still on the long road to meet the Global technical strategy for Malaria 2030 (GTS) and achieve the 3rd Sustainable Development Goal (SDG), particularly target 3.3, which calls for ending epidemics of malaria and other communicable diseases by 2030.

As Nigeria is part of the 11 countries  responsible for 70% and 73% of the Global malaria incidence and malaria mortality respectively, it was extremely necessary for us to attend the conference and be part of the discussion and solution.

The objectives of the conference were to:
https://t.co/1gKmYoJjbn progress and challenges in meeting the GTS Malaria 2030 targets.
2.Discuss mitigation and funding strategies for Malaria prevention and treatment. 
3.Agree on effective strategies and responses for accelerated malaria mortality reduction in Africa, underpinned by a commitment to UHC.
4.Establish a roadmap for increased political commitment and societal engagement in malaria control with a clear accountability mechanism.

At the end of the conference, all Ministers in attendance signed the 2024 Yaoundé Declaration on Malaria, which detailed the contents of the roadmap and our commitment to meet the GTS Malaria targets by 2030.

With a significant increase of funding allocated towards healthcare in our upcoming 2025 budget, the federal government is now poised to increase domestic funding towards our malaria elimination strategy, in line with the 2000 Abuja Declaration.

Coupled with President Bola Ahmed Tinubu’s unwavering support and his commitment to improve our healthcare delivery system and the legislatures to ensure its implementation, Prof @muhammadpate and I will work tirelessly to create an environment where all citizens aren’t easily succumbed to the plight of malaria. 

Our plan is to invest more human resources for health across all levels of care, especially in primary healthcare facilities, work with development partners to direct more funding towards malaria eradication, and strengthen and improve quality data generation to improve decisions.

As a next step, the @Fmohnigeria will be organising a broad, all-encompassing meeting in Abuja focused on “Rethinking Malaria Elimination in Nigeria” in the coming weeks. The achievement of President @officialABAT’s Renewed Hope Agenda and our 4-point vision for a better healthcare system, relies heavily on regulation, consistency and maintenance. 

Today, roughly 60% of our healthcare is delivered through the private sector, leaving 5-10% and 30% to be delivered by the Federal and State government respectively.

The lack of consistent health facility regulation in our sector, has left Nigerians to be preyed upon by ill-equipped, uncertified facilities and poorly qualified healthcare professionals, who face no consequences for their actions. It’s absence also causes saturated need in areas with multiple hospitals and facilities, which in turn affects the interest of foreign investors.

My discussion on Wednesday 27th February, with the State Commissioners of Health at the Quarterly Collaborative Meeting of the National Health Commissioner’s Forum (NHCF), focused on the Federal Government’s plan to implement a National Health Facility Regulatory Commission. The Commission will help to regulate all facilities and healthcare and allied healthcare professionals. The meeting served as a great opportunity to receive the commissioners in-person feedback and gain their support.
 
We have an incredibly complex healthcare system, that requires effective, collaborative governance through all levels (state to federal) to enable Nigerians to receive the highest standards of care, when and where they need it. 

I extend thanks to the State Commissioners for their honest feedback and support to implement the National Health Facility Regulatory Commission. With their support as our co-creators on this journey, our next step is to present this initiative at the next Federal Executive Council meeting and proceed with the legislation.  

We are at a penultimate time in history where the dawn of a rejuvenated healthcare system awaits us. All we need to do is seize it.

text:
#Cancer is one of the leading causes of death worldwide and in Nigeria, with 1 in 5 people being diagnosed with the disease during their lifetime. 

To support Nigerians with the high incurred cost of cancer care, under our strategic guidance, the National Health Insurance Act (NHIA) will ensure all Nigerians including cancer patients are enrolled on a health insurance plan. The NHIA will manage funding for cancer care in the future, to avoid duplication of roles in terms of purchase of services for all patients.

In line with President Bola Ahmed Tinubu’s @officialABAT Renewed Hope Agenda and @Fmohnigeria ’s goal to save lives, reduce physical and financial pain, and produce health for all Nigerias, we finally received the funding needed to build 6 cancer centres in each geopolitical zone.  

These centres will be constructed in the following Federal Teaching Hospitals: UNTH, Enugu (South-East), ABUTH, Zaria, FTH Katsina (North-West), UBTH Benin (South-South), JUTH Jos (North Central), and LUTH, Lagos (South West), while UMTH Maiduguri is being upgraded (North-East).  All centres will be equipped with brachytherapy machines, other state-of-the-art equipment and will have trained biomedical engineers ready to maintain and service the equipment. 

We are also in the process of implementing the 2021 National Policy on Hospice and Palliative care and 2021 National Policy on Chemotherapy Safety. The Ministry will take steps to review the level of implementation of the 2 policy documents with the view to ensuring optimal uptake by the Healthcare providers across the country.

Effective data collection and disease monitoring is key to our health security and  the sector’s growth. To improve the reliability and effectiveness to capture relevant data adequate for the National Planning for Cancer Management, we will be revamping and optimising our current Population Based Cancer Registry (PBCR) to focus on all cancers including paediatric cancers. 

I would like to extend commendations to all bilateral and multilateral organisations, non-governmental organisations, pharmaceutical and equipment manufacturers  collaborating with us to tackle cancer prevalence in Nigeria.

It is only through effective communication, cross- and in-sectoral collaborations through our agencies and public private partnerships that we can provide robust care services to fight cancer in Nigeria. Together, I am confident we can #CloseTheGap (2)

In 2023, we provided single dose HPV vaccines to 7.7 million girls aged 9-14, implemented campaigns in schools and communities to increase the uptake of the vaccines, and encouraged cancer screening at all levels of our healthcare system.

Instead of importing drugs, we want to change our culture of consumption to production. To this effect, we are reviewing our Pharmaceutical Laws and Regulations to encourage local production and are building a robust relationship with the pharmaceutical industry and other relevant stakeholders in the Nigeria Cancer Ecosystem.

To ensure patients with cancer are sustainably treated efficiently and timely, we have moved the Cancer Health Fund originally coordinated and housed in the FMOHSW, to the National Institute of Cancer Research and Treatment (NICRAT) @NicratGov. The recent COVID-19 Pandemic highlighted numerous issues in our health system requiring immediate attention, such as our reliance on imported vaccines for infectious diseases. 

In the global race to achieve SDG 3.8 and Universal Health Coverage, the National Institute of Pharmaceutical Research and Development (NIPRD) and its partners, have developed a bottom-up approach for vaccine research & development (R&D) and local vaccine manufacturing in Nigeria.

Aligned with the Nigerian Vaccine Policy 2021, the National Health Act 2014 and the National Health Sector Blueprint 2024-2026, the National Plan for Vaccine R&D and Local Production 2024-2034 provides nine evidence-based strategies to sustainably establish local vaccine production; in line with President Bola Ahmed Tinubu commitment to Unlock the Value Chain of the Healthcare Sector. 

The ten-year plan addresses critical issues i.e., vaccine distribution, hesitancy and disparities in coverage, provides guidance for relevant stakeholders and insights on multi-sectoral interventions crucial to eradicate vaccine preventable diseases. By the end, it also ensures 3 additional plants become operational in the country.

I extend gratitude and commendations to Dr Obi Adigwe, Director General NIPRID, NIPRD’s partners – the Bulgarian Government, represented by Ambassador Dr Yanko Yordanov, and EU delegation in Nigeria for recognising the criticality of this intervention and prioritising the expedited development of this important initiative.

The Federal Ministry of Health and Social Welfare will continue to provide the necessary support and will work with all relevant agencies and sector actors to ensure our desired result of delivering a sustainable vaccine R&D and local production in the country is achieved.
